title: Spending Alignment
description: Assess how aligned you feel about spending priorities

questions.text: I feel my partner and I have compatible views on what's worth spending money on.

therapeutic.rationale: Compatibility in spending priorities reduces future conflict. Even before merging finances, you can observe what your partner values enough to spend on—and whether that aligns with your values.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: A perceived gap in spending compatibility deserves discussion. Often couples discover more alignment than expected once they understand each other's reasoning.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of spending compatibility creates confidence about your financial future together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does your partner spend on that you admire? What concerns you?

questions.text: I respect how my partner chooses to spend their money.

therapeutic.rationale: Respect for your partner's spending choices—even when different from yours—reflects acceptance. Judgment about spending often becomes control or conflict later.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels less respected for their spending, explore what's driving the judgment. Understanding the 'why' behind spending often builds respect.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual respect for each other's spending choices creates space for individuality within partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Is there something your partner spends on that you struggle to respect? What would help?

questions.text: I believe we could agree on big purchases together.

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence in making big decisions together reflects trust in your partnership. Even before facing major purchases, this belief shapes how you approach financial planning.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different confidence levels may reflect different decision-making styles. Discuss how you'd approach a big purchase to build shared confidence.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in making big decisions together is a foundation for future financial partnership.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you approach a major purchase decision together? What might be challenging?

questions.text: I don't feel judged by my partner for my spending choices.

therapeutic.rationale: Feeling judged for spending creates shame and secrecy. Partners who feel accepted spend more openly and honestly, even when their choices differ.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels judged, the other may not realize how their comments land. Discuss what creates the sense of judgment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual freedom from judgment creates an environment where you can be honest about money.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you ever hide spending from your partner? What drives that?

questions.text: I feel we balance enjoying money now with being responsible for the future.

therapeutic.rationale: The tension between present enjoyment and future security is universal. Feeling balanced here suggests you've found—or believe you can find—a middle ground that works for both.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceptions of balance often reflect different risk tolerances or life experiences. Explore what 'balanced' means to each of you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of balance creates alignment on how to approach spending and saving.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you lean more toward enjoying now or saving for later? Does your partner know this about you?
